currently watching: Mulholland Drive

 

SEE THIS MOVIE SEE THIS MOVIE SEE THIS MOVIE.

it's a masterpiece, and David Lynch is a genius.

definitely one of the most challenging films i've ever watched. it's an unexpectedly complex riddle. chekov's pistol is not to be underestimated/overlooked. pay attention to every detail. be aware of the implications of things. allusions (like the Rita Hayworth allusion? still haven't figured that one out...) are significant. take note of the characters-when they appear, under what circumstances, who they appear with, and where. this is a flim-noir-esque surrealistic tale that has everything in it- from  magical realism, suspense, tragedy, mystery, denial, deception, lies, disillusionment, revenge, corruption, murder, desperation, jealousy, the seediness behind the glitz and glamour of hollywood, false hopes, and, the saddest of all, ruin. mulholland drive is above all, a tragedy. (an Aristotelian tragedy at that, i must say). it will raise goosebumps, give you the chills, make you cry- not only because of the masterful cinematic aspects and the dangerous, suspenseful plot, but from the gripping emotional trauma. there is no greater, more awful tragedy than being broken. seeing something that was once so full of promise come desperately unraveled is heartbreaking.

David Lynch sure puts a very unorthodox, original, and ingenious spin on things. despite the surrealism that abounds in mulholland drive, his way of capturing the reality (and un-reality) is as we see it: tangled up in conflicting desires, clouded by emotion, wishful thinking, and, at times, vengeful contempt. the truth is, we don't view reality in a linear, unresolving motion. we have flashbacks, fantasies, regrets, we envision scenarios of how things might have been. though we exist physically in reality and in the present, the scope of our existence is so much more- our memories, dreams, desires, emotions- all constitute the true reality we live in everyday. this movie is essentially a trip through somebody's mind- and more realistic than you think. i'm not sure if this movie was partly a social commentary and/or satire-esque rude awakening about the disillusionment of Hollywood, but it did bear those overtones at times. the film is slightly reminiscent of movies like Memento in its suspenseful nonlinear plot; it has an early 1900s mobster feel as well as Hitchcock-esque elements, and the subtle, charming 1950's vibe really brings a sense of nostalgia back into Hollywood cinema. but really, no other archetype or style comes close to describing this.

i've been wanting to get into David Lynch's work forever, and, this being the first of his work i've seen, i am enormously impressed. his style is definitely is an acquired taste, and if you don't like movies that tie your mind in knots, make you think, or cause you to reevaluate the way reality is percieved, then don't watch this movie -you'll only frustrate yourself. it definitely is very difficult to understand on the first viewing, simply because the way it's presented is so unexpected. if it helps, here's the best advice i can give while watching it for the first time: think of it from a metaphysical perspective- what is significant is more important than what actually happens. I love how Lynch doesn't insult the audience by handing anything out on a silver platter- he only hints, gives subtle clues, and trusts you to solve the puzzle yourself.

there are countless little aspects of this film i'd love to delve into, but i don't want to ruin it for anyone (if you want to discuss it, by all means i am willing!). all i can say is that it is not for the faint of heart. this is one film that will continue to haunt you for a long, long time, and you will discover new things about it everytime you watch it. in short, it's fucking brilliant. go ahead, open Pandora's Box. Take a trip down Mulholland Drive. don't miss out.

In a perfect world, we would treat February 14th the same way we treat March 8th, December 4th, July 27th, or June 10th. Why? you ask. I mean, what is significant about those dates?

Exactly.

Until a peaceful February 14th of the future comes, a day in which we all collectively forget to imbue it with any higher significance whatsoever, I will inevitably continue to feel anti-Vday sentiments. Yes yes, I am a hypocrite; shame on me. In feeling antagonism toward it, I am furthering its grip on my world. I should just be indifferent, or better yet, forget it's anything but numbers on a calendar. Somebody please punish me, quick.

How easy to think, Oh Jessica, you're so bitter because you're celebrating Single's Awareness Day. Well, i have the same sentiments toward Mother's and Father's Day; does that mean i'm an orphan? Not at all, in fact, i have great parents and i love them. What i do not love are the manifestations of just how much Hallmark and all the other corporations involved have managed to manipulate the minds and souls of the general populace. It's brilliant advertising: we actually feel guilty for not buying a card/fancy dinner/Ipod/vibrator/European tour/house in the Hamptons for our loved ones. We actually get depressed when our loved ones don't shower us with lavish gifts that result in month-long starvation in order to appease the Visa/Mastercard/American Express gods. After all, if people fail to buy buy buy whenever Hallmark & Co commands, it must mean they don't truly love you. Money can buy love, don't you know? And if you don't understand this, then you don't know what love is.

It's not a sin for Hallmark & Co. to take advantage of our potential gullibility, insecurity, and narcissism in order to make us buy crap we don't need. But that doesn't mean that we as consumers should allow ourselves to be victimized. Showing love is great, but we can do that whenever we want. Don't most people love spontanaeity anyway? So take Vday and all commercial holidays with a grain of salt. Enjoy them for what they are-  commercial holidays; fun at times, but not to be taken to heart. Celebrate if you want, but getting depressed, jealous, feeling obligated, going broke, risking your life, and making a big fucking deal out of a Hallmark Holiday is not advised. It's downright unhealthy and besides, do you really want everyone to know you're bored enough to be obsessing about something this trivial?

I confess: as much as I would love to see Valentine's day disappear off the radar of our cultural consciousness like a traitor in the Soviet Union, i actually kind of like this day. I have a lifelong love affair with the color pink. I find chocolate (especially of the dark variety) irresistable. I get addicted to those cute, pastel-colored, chalky-textured candy hearts. I enjoy sending my friends Vday mail (yeah, so i guess i give in, but i value my friends more than spreading anti-Vday propaganda). It's all in good fun. It's pretty. But it doesn't go beyond that.

So here I am on Single's Awareness Day, it's rainy, cold, and dreary, and I'm happy. Oh no...heaven forbid I enjoy being single on this day and fail to bring about the onset of depression/fear of self-effacement! Nobody loves me! Right. But i do admit, having experienced this singledom 18 out of the 19 Valentine's Days in my life, being single is preferable. No expectations, no headache over dinner reservations, no quixotic notions and/or play-by-play analysis of the (mis)fortunes that this day has in the grand scheme of an entire courtship. (Not that those circumstances shouldn't apply to people who are in relationships). Anyway, I'm very happy to be single and yes, it is a choice. Reading my journal entry from this day last year (in which i was in a serious relationship), i'm glad to see that i felt very much the same then as i do now.

However you spent this Hallmark Field-Day, dear reader, i hope it went well and i hope you are happy. If you're not, however, then you then you can blame only yourself for being lame enough to care too much.
